The potential role of metal-support interaction for tuning the product selectivity during atmospheric pressure CO2 hydrogenation has been demonstrated on Pd/(Ti)-SBA-15 catalyst. Highly dispersed Pd NPs on SBA-15 (Pd/SBA-15) was synthesized and further modified with titanium of varying composition. Comparison of catalytic activity of Pd/Ti-SBA-15 with its counterparts (Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2) illustrated the significance of strong Pd-Ti interface in this catalyst and its role in tuning the product selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation. The generation of an ample amount of oxygen vacancies in the Pd/Ti-SBA-15 catalyst with maximum metallic Pd sites in close vicinity of Ti is proposed to boost the CO2 hydrogenation activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Modified deposition precipitation CO2 hydrogenation Metal-support interaction Oxygen vacancies Titanosilicates 1 Introduction Modern trends of civilization and our critical dependence on fossil fuels have tremendously increased the anthropogenic CO2 emission in the environment. Even though CO2 is a non-poisonous gas it is one of the major constituents of greenhouse gasses and its continuous emission in the earth's atmosphere has severely affected the global climate resulting in global warming and ocean acidification [1]. Considering the adverse effect of changes in the global climate it is highly recommended to cut CO2 emission to restrict the temperature increase to 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels. CO2 capture and sequestration (CCS) have emerged as the potential mitigation route and are anticipated to reduce the CO2 emission to 19% as required by 2050, [2,3] but its potential leakage limits the use of this method as an effective solution. Also, the development of this process is slow and unpopular due to its high process and construction cost especially in developing countries [4]. Chemical transformation of CO2 to valuable products is the most attractive alternative to mitigate CO2 emissions and can be achieved via photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, and thermal catalysis [5–8]. However, the conversion and selectivity are not so impressive due to very high stability of the CO2 molecule. Heterogeneous hydrogenation of CO2 can produce various molecules such as CO, hydrocarbons, oxygenates such as alcohols, formic acid, etc. by tuning the reaction conditions as well as catalysts [9–11]. High pressure of feed gasses is usually required to obtain an optimum yield of higher hydrocarbons (C2+) and oxygenates. Atmospheric pressure conversion of CO2 most often results in C1 products such as CO, CH4, and sometimes methanol also but in a very small yield. While CO is an important feedstock molecule of Fischer Tropsch (FT) synthesis, [12,13] CH4 is an important fuel used as natural gas and a major source of H2 generation by steam reforming [14]. Various transition metal-based catalysts have been reported for CO2 conversion to C1 products and activity can be tuned for a specific product by tuning the catalyst's properties [15]. The stability of the intermediates formed during the reaction decides the selectivity of different products. Apart from the metal used, another important parameter that can switch the product selectivity is metal support interaction [16]. Considerable efforts have been devoted to understanding the elementary steps and sites required for CO2 conversion at the metal/support interface. However, the exact reaction mechanisms and their intermediates are still controversial. Stabilization of reaction intermediates at particular sites can be one of the deciding factors for selectivity switch. Recent literature reports have shown the effect of metal-support interaction on product selectivity [16,17]. Cu/ZrO2 catalyst shows the crucial role of metal-support interaction in stabilizing the formate intermediate species which were responsible for getting high methanol selectivity [18]. Rh NPs supported on reducible support interestingly showed the formation of adsorbate induced strong metal-support interaction which changed the selectivity from CH4 to CO hence proving the crucial role of metal-support interaction [19]. Photoelectrochemical CO2 conversion to CO and H2 over Pt/TiO2 showed high efficiency due to synergistic interaction at the Pt-Ti interface which structurally provided sites for CO2 conversion to CO [20]. These reports emphasize the role of the metal-support interface in fine-tuning the conversion and selectivity for CO2 hydrogenation. Pd is one of the important hydrogenation catalysts and its catalytic activity for CO2 hydrogenation at atmospheric pressure usually proceeds through RWGS (reverse water gas shift) reaction as the dominant pathway thus forming CO as the major product [21]. In the present study, we have synthesized Pd supported on SBA-15 by modified deposition precipitation (DP) method using NH4Cl as the in-situ modifier of Pd precursor which helped in the successful deposition of small Pd NPs on SBA-15 with desired loading [22] and was further modified with titanium to obtain Pd/Ti-SBA-15. The synthesized Pd catalysts with variable Si/Ti molar ratios were screened for CO2 hydrogenation at atmospheric pressure and compared with TiO2 and SBA-15 supports. Ti modified silica has most often been considered as the oxidation catalyst especially for epoxidation reaction however its hydrogenation property has been scarcely reported [23]. The present work has demonstrated the utility of Ti modified SBA-15 (Ti-SBA-15) as the heterogeneous support for CO2 hydrogenation. It has been observed that both conversions, as well as selectivity, can be tuned by modifying Pd/SBA-15 catalyst with titanium. The role of oxygen vacancies generated in the support after Ti modification and synergistic interactions at the Pd-Ti interface are found to show peculiar behavior in terms of conversion and selectivity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Pd/SBA-15 catalyst Small Pd NPs were supported on SBA-15 by the modified DP method [22,24]. Briefly, 500 mg of SBA-15 support was dispersed in water to which 53.4 mg NH4Cl was added. Then the pH of the solution was maintained at 9–9.5 using NaOH solution and the required amount of Pd precursor, H2PdCl4 (to obtain Pd loading of 4 wt%) was added dropwise while maintaining the pH. The catalyst was further stirred for an hour after which the catalyst was collected and dried at 70 °C overnight. The final catalyst was obtained after calcination at 400 oC for 4 h. 2.2 Modification of Pd/SBA-15 catalyst with titanium The as-synthesized Pd/SBA-15 catalyst without calcination was further modified with titanium by the post grafting method. Titanium(IV)tetraisopropoxide (TIP) was used as titanium precursor. Before adding it to the Pd/SBA-15 catalyst TIP was modified with acetylacetonate (acac) to prevent the rapid hydrolysis of TIP. The required amount of TIP was added to acac in ethanol and vigorously stirred for 1h. Meanwhile, Pd/SBA-15 catalyst was dispersed in ethanol and modified titanium-acac precursor was added to this solution. The catalyst was further agitated at moderate rpm for 3 h. The catalyst was collected after evaporating ethanol at 40 °C under rotary evaporation and dried at 70 °C. The final titanium modified Pd/SBA-15 catalyst was obtained after calcination at 400 °C for 4 h. Depending upon the Si/Ti ratio used in the synthesis, the catalyst was designated as PdTS-x (PdTS-1, PdTS-5, PdTS-10, PdTS-25 etc.) where x denoted Si/Ti molar ratio. The Pd loading was 4 wt%. For comparison, Pd/TiO2 of similar Pd loading was also synthesized by the wet impregnation method. Pd/TS-5 catalyst was also synthesised to compare it with PdTS-5 as a control experiment. Pd/TS-5 was synthesised by first modifying the SBA-15 with required amount of titanium to form TS-5 support and then Pd was supported on this by wet impregnation and the final Pd/TS-5 catalyst was obtained after calcination at 400 °C. 2.3 Catalyst characterization DRUV analysis was done by Shimadzu 2700 spectrophotometer with an integrated dual-beam source equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment. He lamp and tungsten lamp were the UV and visible light sources respectively and BaSO4 was used as the standard. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured with Micromeritics Tristar 3000 apparatus with an adsorption analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature. Before analysis, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. The specific surface areas were measured from the BET method at relative pressure ranging from 0.05 to 0.2. The total pore volumes were determined by total volume adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.95. The pore size distribution curves were obtained from the desorption branch of isotherm using the BJH equation. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a HUBER G-670 diffractometer fitted with an anti-cathode Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å). XRD patterns were recorded over 2θ values ranging from 10° to 80°, with a scanning rate of 5 s/step and 0.05 step sizes. Low-angle XRD patterns were recorded on a D8 advances X-ray diffractometer (Bruker AXS) fitted with a CuKα (λ =1.5406 Ao) range 0.5–6° with 0.02° steps. TEM analysis was carried out by TECHNAI FEI instrument working at a voltage of 200 kV with LaB6 as the filament. The samples for TEM analysis were prepared in ethanol, dropcasted on carbon-coated copper grid and dried completely before analysis. XPS measurements were carried out using the Thermo Kalpha+ spectrometer using micro-focused and monochromated Al Kα radiation with energy 1486.6 eV. The pass energy for the spectral acquisition was kept at 50 eV for individual core-levels. The electron flood gun was utilized for providing charge compensation during data acquisition. Palletized samples were used for analysis. The peak fitting of the individual core-levels was done using XPS peak-41 software with a Shirley-type background. 2.4 CO2 hydrogenation All catalytic tests were carried out in a plug-flow tubular quartz reactor of 30 cm length and an inner diameter of 6 mm. The reactor was fixed inside a carbolite vertical furnace equipped with a programmable temperature controller. Typically, 100 mg powder catalyst was sieved and loaded into the reactor. Prior to CO2 hydrogenation, all the catalysts were reduced in situ at 400 °C under pure stream of H2 for 3 h. The catalysts were then cooled to 100 °C by continuously flowing H2. CO2, H2 and N2 were passed through the reactor with a ratio of 1:3:0.5 (N2 is used as an internal standard for GC analysis) and catalytic bed temperature was increased to reaction temperature. The flow rate of feed gases was 9 ml/min with a GHSV of 5400 mL (gcat•h)−1 and controlled by individual Alicat mass flow controllers. The effluent gas from the reactor was analyzed by using an online gas chromatograph (Nucon 5765, GC) equipped with two columns in parallel: one is a HP plot-Q capillary column connected to a flame ionization detector (FID) for the analysis of hydrocarbons and the other a carbosieve packed column connected to a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for the analysis of permanent gases H2, CO, CO2 and CH4. The stability tests were performed under the same space velocity at 673 K for 24 h. The conversion of CO2 (XCO2) was calculated using the formula below [25,26] X CO 2 ( % ) = [ CO 2 ] in − [ CO 2 ] out [ CO 2 ] in × 100 % where [ C O 2 ] in and [ C O 2 ] out represent the concentration of CO2 in the inlet and outlet feed gas respectively. The selectivity S for different products was calculated as: S ( spec ific prod uct ) ( % ) = % specific product % total product × 100 % where% specific product was calculated from standard GC calibration. 3 Results and discussion The synthesized catalysts were investigated by microscopic and spectroscopic characterization techniques to correlate the physicochemical properties with the catalytic activity. The modification of silica by titanium can result in titanium occupying either the silica lattice or present as the extra framework, phase segregated titania domains. The preliminary information about the nature of titanium in silica lattice as obtained from DRUV analysis can be seen in Fig. 1 which shows that titanium has occupied the silica lattice as indicated by the presence of a band at 220–230 nm which signifies the charge transfer between tetrahedral titanium Ti4+ and O2− ions [27,28]. For perfect isolated tetrahedral titanium in silica lattice, this band appears at 210–220 nm but the redshift in this band is due to the distorted tetrahedral geometry of titanium in silica [29,30]. Another band between 260 and 290 nm was also observed due to the presence of extra framework titanium or titanium in octahedral coordination in silica lattice. The broadening of this band was observed on moving from PdTS-25 to PdTS-1 indicating the formation of phase segregated titania due to increased loading of titanium in PdTS-1. In PdTS-1 this band showed features similar to titania which indicates that complete phase segregation happened on moving from PdTS-50 to PdTS-1. The presence of a band in the range of 400–500 nm can be attributed to oxidized Pd NPs which appeared due to the charge transfer between Pd2+ and O2− ions [31] and can be observed in all the PdTS catalysts. Thus, DRUV analysis shows that along with tetrahedral titanium in the silica lattice phase segregated titanium was also present when weight loading of titanium increased beyond Si/Ti ratio 5 which is further supported by wide-angle XRD analysis. Fig. 2 shows the XRD plots of these catalysts in both small and wide-angle range. The small-angle XRD of the catalysts as shown in Fig. 2a, exhibited the major reflections at 0.93, 1.63, and 1.86 which correspond to the ordered 2D hexagonal mesoporous structure of SBA-15 with a space group of p6mm [32]. The intensity of these peaks was maximum in pristine SBA-15 and decreased after deposition of Pd as well as Ti incorporation. However, the presence of these peaks in all the samples except PdTS-1 confirmed that the mesoporous structure of SBA-15 was preserved even after Pd and Ti loading. In PdTS-1 the structure collapsed drastically which was reflected as a feeble peak at 0.93° while other reflections were completely vanished indicating the discontinuity in the regular mesoporous structure of SBA-15. Small-angle XRD analysis thus confirmed the successful deposition of Pd as well as the incorporation of Ti in the mesoporous channels while maintaining the inherent mesoporosity of SBA-15. In the wide-angle XRD analysis (Fig. 2b), Pd/SBA-15 catalyst did not show any reflections of PdO which is due to the presence of highly dispersed small-sized Pd NPs in SBA-15 channels. After titanium modification, clear reflection from PdO (101) could be seen at 33.8° which showed that titanium addition increased the size of Pd NPs as observed from DRUV analysis also. The particle size calculation from the Scherrer formula showed that PdTS-1 and Pd/TiO2 had Pd NPs of size 8 nm while PdTS-5, 10, and 25 showed particles of size 6–7 nm. Moreover, the reflections from phase segregated titanium were not visible up to PdTS-10. A weak reflection at 25.5° can be seen in PdTS-5 due to the presence of some extra framework titania whose intensity increased sharply in PdTS-1 matching completely to Pd/TiO2 thereby confirming the phase segregation of anatase TiO2 from silica [33]. Thus, XRD analysis corroborates the results obtained from DRUV that incorporation of titanium in Pd/SBA-15 catalyst results in the formation of extra framework titania in PdTS-5 with complete phase segregation of titania in PdTS-1 catalyst. Further, TEM was carried out for morphological analysis of the prepared catalysts. The TEM images (Fig. 3 ) showed that mesoporous channels of SBA-15 were still maintained after titanium incorporation except for PdTS-1 where phase segregated titania destroyed the typical mesoporous architecture. The Pd/SBA-15 catalyst showed highly dispersed small-sized (2–3 nm) Pd NPs mostly appeared encapsulated in mesoporous channels of SBA-15. The Pd particle size was maintained in PdTS-50 to PdTS-5 where highly dispersed Pd NPs in mesoporous channels were evident but with some morphology destruction. Pd/TiO2 catalyst showed the titania particles of size 20–30 nm with Pd NPs of size 7–8 nm which was similar to that calculated from XRD. Pd NPs in all the PdTS-x catalysts showed almost similar size in the range of 5–6 nm except PdTS-1 where particle size was similar to the Pd/TiO2 catalyst. SEM-EDAX analysis of these catalysts showed an increase in titanium from 1.7 wt% to 20% on increasing the Si/Ti ratio from 50 to 1. The content of titanium obtained in PdTS 50, 25, 10, 5, and 1 was 1.7, 3.5, 6.6, 14, and 20 wt %, respectively. The textural properties of the synthesized catalysts were explored by N2 Porosimetry analysis. N2 adsorption-desorption plots and distribution of pores size of different catalysts can be seen in Fig. S1 and S1 Inset. All the catalysts followed type IV isotherm hysteresis corresponding to the filling of mesopores in the pressure range of 0.6–0.9. However, PdTS-1 catalyst showed the minimum amount of N2 adsorption and in the range of 0.5–0.8 as compared to other PdTS-x catalysts which indicated the pore blocking of SBA-15 upon the introduction of titanium. Table S1 represents the textural properties of the catalysts. As expected, the BET surface area and pore volume of Pd/SBA-15 were maximum compared to titanium modified catalysts. On the other hand, among PdTS-x catalysts, PdTS-1 showed the minimum surface area with the lowest pore diameter and pore volume. This is obvious since the amount of titanium in this catalyst destroyed the mesoporosity of silica. As observed in DRUV analysis, the occupancy of titanium in the tetrahedral/octahedral environment in the PdTS-x catalyst showed both the features which were further confirmed by XPS analysis. The surface sensitivity of XPS provides essential information about the chemical nature, and the concentration of active surface species, making it the most sought technique in catalysis [34]. The tetra coordinated titanium shows binding energy at a higher region as compared to octahedral coordinated Ti4+ ions. Ti 2p core level XPS analysis done on PdTS-x catalysts showed both the features at 458.8 and 459.9 eV for octahedral and tetrahedral coordination, respectively, as seen in Fig. 4 a [35,36]. However, small TiO2 clusters of size < 5 nm highly dispersed in silica show binding energy values similar to tetrahedrally coordinated Ti [35]. But in the present case, DRUV analysis showed a UV band at 220–230 nm, which is typically for tetra coordinated Ti in silica lattice. It can be seen that with increasing amount of titanium the contribution of tetrahedral Ti4+ decreased (lowest for PdTS-1), due to the formation of phase segregated titania. Since the CO2 hydrogenation was performed on reduced catalysts, we followed a similar protocol for recording the XPS spectra also. The XPS analysis on reduced catalysts showed another feature towards lower binding energy at 457.8 eV. This peak can be attributed to Ti3+ ions due to the generation of oxygen vacancies in the hydrogen environment [30,37]. From Fig. 4b it can be observed that PdTS-5 showed the maximum amount of Ti3+ (16%), which can be directly correlated to the amount of oxygen vacancies generated. Interestingly Pd/TiO2 did not show any oxygen vacancy generation, which shows that introduction of titanium in silica could potentially generate defect centres in the support. To explore more about Pd-Ti electronic interaction Pd 3d XPS spectra were recorded (Fig. 5 ) for these catalysts. The XPS spectra of Pd showed two peaks at 335.2 and 336.8 eV which correspond to metallic Pd and Pd in +2 oxidation state respectively [22,38]. The amount of metallic Pd increased as the amount of Ti increased from PdTS-25 to PdTS-1 and Pd/TiO2 showed the maximum amount of metallic Pd (84%) due to the pure titania phase. PdTS-5 catalyst showed the maximum amount of oxygen vacancies with an appreciable amount of metallic Pd. Thus, XPS analysis strongly points towards the increased metal-support interaction in Pd/SBA-15 catalyst after titanium modification, which resulted in a sufficient amount of oxygen vacancy generation while maintaining the metallic character of Pd. For comparison, the XPS analysis of TS-5 alone was carried out after the reduction in the same conditions as that of PdTS-5. It was observed that support alone showed only 4% oxygen vacancy generation as compared to PdTS-5 which showed 16% of oxygen vacancies (Fig. S2). This indicates that Pd helped in the oxygen vacancy generation in the support at the interface. This is feasible as hydrogen activation is facile on Pd NPs which in turn can spill over and react with the oxygen of support at the metal-support interface thereby creating oxygen vacancies. This has been evidenced by supporting Pd on TS-5 support to form Pd/TS-5 catalyst which was analyzed by XPS after reduction treatment similar to other PdTS-x catalysts. It is noteworthy that after supporting Pd, 7% of Ti3+ sites were generated which indeed was less as compared to PdTS-5 (16%) (Fig. S3) but more than the TS-5 support alone. This kind of metal-assisted oxygen vacancy generation in the support is a well-documented phenomenon in literature where metal NPs at the perimeter sites help in the generation of defect centers under reaction conditions [39,40]. Supports like CeO2, TiO2, Fe2O3, etc. are known to generate oxygen vacancies when close to metal NPs [41]. It is noteworthy that the oxygen vacancy in the support increased from PdTS-25 to PdTS-5 and further decreased in PdTS-1 and a negligible amount was present in Pd/TiO2. This oxygen vacancy generation can be attributed to the strong interaction between Pd and Ti. The catalytic activity of the synthesized materials was tested for atmospheric pressure CO2 hydrogenation in the temperature range of 473–673 K with CO2 to H2 ratio as 1:3. All the catalysts were pre-treated in the H2 atmosphere at 400 °C with a flow of 15 ml/min for 3 h to ensure the reduction of Pd to metallic form. The CO2 hydrogenation activity results can be seen in Fig. 6 . The activity plot in Fig. 6a shows the CO2 conversion of different catalysts at different temperatures and the only products formed were CO and CH4. It can be observed that initial activity for all the catalysts and their conversion below 550 K was marginal, but after increasing the temperature beyond 593 K the difference in activity was observed, and finally, at 673 K PdTS-5 catalyst showed the highest CO2 conversion of 31%. A difference in the selectivity of these catalysts at different temperatures was also observed (Fig. 6b). Initially, at lower temperatures, all the catalysts showed RWGS as the dominant reaction pathway making CO the major product (Eq. (1)). (1) CO 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O But with an increase in the temperature selectivity switched from CO to CH4 except for Pd/SBA-15 which showed CO as the major product throughout the temperature range. The selectivity trend for Pd/TiO2 was also interesting to note here as it showed very high selectivity for CO up to 623 K. Thus, it can be inferred that Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2 showed similar selectivity and activity trend in a large temperature window. For both Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2 catalysts the conversion was below 10% with CO as the major product, thus making RWGS the dominant reaction. But the modification of Pd/SBA-15 with titanium resulted in improved CO2 conversion with a selectivity switch from CO to CH4 hence turning the RWGS reaction to complete hydrogenation of CO2. More interestingly, the selectivity switch toward methane was observed in the PdTS-5 catalyst even at (513 K) demonstrating the influence of Ti incorporation. Thus, with a nominal loading of Ti (14%) a PdTS-5 catalyst showed 78% methane selectivity with conversion close to 31% at 673 K in comparison with the Pd-TiO2 catalyst which gave only 8% conversion with 30% methane selectivity. The other PdTS catalysts also showed a similar trend but were inferior as compared to the PdTS-5 catalyst. As a control experiment, the Pd/TS-5 catalyst was also tested and its activity was compared with PdTS-5 (Fig. 7 ). It can be observed from the plots that the Pd/TS-5 catalyst showed less CO2 conversion as compared to the PdTS-5 catalyst. At 673 K PdTS-5 showed 31% CO2 conversion while Pd/TS-5 showed only 14% conversion. The selectivity was also different for this catalyst as compared to PdTS-5. This catalyst showed a maximum of 56% CH4 selectivity while the PdTS-5 catalyst showed 78% CH4 selectivity. TEM analysis of the Pd/TS-5 catalyst showed the strong structural similarity of these two catalysts (Figs. 3f and S4) and eliminated any particle size driven activity changes since the size of Pd NPs was similar to the PdTS-5 catalyst. The CO2 activity results of these catalysts showed the peculiarity of the employed synthesis protocol on CO2 conversion as well as product selectivity proving that activity difference can be solely attributed to the strong metal-support interface formed in the PdTS-5 catalyst. Thus, it can be concluded that in the PdTS-5 catalyst where Ti was incorporated into the Pd/SBA-15 catalyst the chances of intimate interaction of Pd-Ti were more as compared to supporting Pd after the synthesis of TS-5 support. The improved CO2 conversion on reduced Pd/SBA-15 catalyst after titanium modification can be attributed to the generation of oxygen vacancies in the support as shown by Ti 2p XPS plots in Fig. 5. Pd/TiO2 catalyst showed very less conversion similar to Pd/SBA-15 catalyst and can be correlated to the absence of oxygen vacancies in both the supports. The oxygen vacancies play an important role in catalysis. These are electronically rich sites where an electron-deficient reactant molecule can get adsorbed and activated by the transfer of electrons to the antibonding orbitals of the reactant molecule. CO2 being a Lewis acid can easily interact with these sites and gets activated. Thus, the PdTS-5 catalyst, due to presence of oxygen vacancies, showed improved CO2 conversion as compared to other catalysts. Depending upon the strength of the binding of CO on the catalyst it can desorb or take part in further hydrogenation. The former case results in the formation of CO and H2O while in the latter case it can form CH4 as the major product [16]. It is well known that the stability of intermediates highly depends upon the nature of active sites. The high binding strength provided by the active sites decides the fate of the final product. In the case of Pd/SBA-15, the Pd-Si interface is not strong enough to strongly adsorb the formed CO which could undergo further hydrogenation. Therefore, the CO desorbs in the form of the product. However, in the case of the PdTS-x catalyst, the intimate synergy of Pd-Ti3+can strengthen the binding of intermediate CO species which can further react with hydrogen atoms present on Pd to form CH4 as the major product. It can be argued why the Pd/TiO2 catalyst where a stronger chance of the Pd-Ti interface can be possible, does not show similar activity to those of PdTS-x catalysts. The Pd particle size effect cannot be a factor as the Pd NPs size is in the range of 6–8 nm in all these catalysts. Such activity difference can only be explained by the nature of the Pd-Ti interface formed on Pd/TiO2 and PdTS-x catalysts. It is obvious that an interface formed by metal NPs with nano support will always be stronger and have different properties than that of bulk support. Also, the no. of active sites increases when size reduces from bulk to nano. In the case of PdTS-x catalysts, the dispersion of Ti in SBA-15 in octahedral or tetrahedral Ti close to Pd could form the stronger and higher amount of Pd-Ti3+ interface due to enhanced charge transfer between metal and support in either of the way. The presence of Pd in close vicinity of Ti is indispensable which is further proved by XPS spectra of PdTS-5 and Pd/TS-5 (Fig.S3). Both the catalysts showed the presence of Ti3+still the activity of PdTS-5 was higher due to the presence of Pd in immediate contact of Ti3+rendering strong Pd-Ti3+interfacial sites. These sites provided much stronger binding to intermediate CO as compared to Pd/TiO2 hence resulted in a selectivity switch from CO to CH4. This kind of change in the selectivity has been observed on Pt-based heterogeneous catalysts where the Pt/TiO2 catalyst showed selectivity for CO while Pt/ZrO2 or CeO2 showed selectivity towards CH4. Thus, the generation of plenty of oxygen vacancies along with the strong Pd-Ti3+interaction led to an enhanced CO2 conversion and improved CH4 selectivity respectively in the PdTS-5 catalyst. Moreover, the stability of the PdTS-5 catalyst under reaction conditions was evaluated by screening the catalyst on stream for 24 h at 673 K. The catalyst showed consistent CO2 conversion while maintaining the stable selectivity for both the products (Fig. 8 ). It is clear from the figure that the methane and CO selectivity did not change throughout the time with a steady CO2 conversion. This shows that the integral properties of the catalyst remained intact throughout the reaction which provided a stable conversion and product selectivity as can be seen in spent catalyst TEM images. The catalyst showed no signs of particle sintering and destruction in the morphology (Fig. 9 ). Comparison of XPS spectra of spent PdTS-5 catalyst with Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2 is shown in Fig. 10 . The Ti 2p spectra of catalysts showed that the PdTS-5 catalyst still carried oxygen vacancies which were possible since the reaction conditions were overall reducing. But Pd/TiO2 catalyst similar to freshly reduced catalyst did not show any oxygen vacancy generation. Pd 3d spectra of the spent catalysts represent that the PdTS-5 catalyst showed only two peaks at 335.3 and 336.8 eV which correspond to metallic Pd and Pd2+. But for Pd/TiO2 and Pd/SBA-15 catalysts a peak at higher binding energy, 338 eV also emerged along with the other two peaks. The peak at higher binding energy corresponds to high valent Pd4+ species [22,38]. The higher oxidation of Pd NPs in Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2 catalysts in the reaction conditions could be attributed to the weak interaction of Pd with support while in the PdTS-5 catalyst strong Pd-Ti interaction maintained Pd in the metallic state. Also, the RWGS is the major reaction in Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2 where water is formed as a byproduct which can oxidize Pd NPs. Therefore, weak interaction with supports and formation of water due to RWGS led to the formation of highly oxidized Pd species in Pd/SBA-15 and Pd-TiO2. The conservation of the metallic nature of Pd NPs in the PdTS-5 catalyst under reaction condition resulted in strong adsorption of intermediate CO species on these sites which further interacted with nearby H to selectively form CH4. This behavior of the PdTS-5 catalyst under reaction condition enforces the critical role of metal-support interaction in CO2 hydrogenation by effectively tuning the properties of active sites which in turn resulted in improved CO2 conversion and change in selectivity from CO to CH4. 4 Conclusion The present work demonstrates the synthesis of tailored Pd/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts where the size of Pd NPs was 6–7 nm with both tetrahedral and octahedral titanium species dispersed in the silica framework. Physicochemical properties confirm the mesoporous nature of the catalysts after Pd and titanium deposition with a destruction in the morphology by increasing the Ti content beyond PdTS-5. Detailed XPS analysis provided evidence for the generation of metal NPs mediated oxygen vacancies in the Ti-SBA-15 support which played the dual role: (i) preserving the metallic character of Pd and (ii) activation of reactant molecules. The strong synergy between Pd-Ti3+ tailored the interfacial sites which helped to switch the product selectivity from CO (in Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2) to CH4 (in PdTS-x). The activity difference between PdTS-5 and Pd/TS-5 in terms of both conversion and selectivity clearly demonstrated how the catalyst synthesis procedure can affect the activity of two catalysts with similar Pd and Ti compositions by generating a strong metal-support interaction. The electronic perturbations generated at the interface due to metal-support interaction modified the properties on both support as well as metal NPs and facilitated the catalytic reaction. The stability of the intermediate on different supports decided the selectivity for a particular product. The present study provides an elegant example of metal-support interaction induced product switch which provides the platform for studying a wide range of reactions where selectivity can be easily altered. coredata.dc:description: The potential role of metal-support interaction for tuning the product selectivity during atmospheric pressure CO2 hydrogenation has been demonstrated on Pd/(Ti)-SBA-15 catalyst. Highly dispersed Pd NPs on SBA-15 (Pd/SBA-15) was synthesized and further modified with titanium of varying composition. Comparison of catalytic activity of Pd/Ti-SBA-15 with its counterparts (Pd/SBA-15 and Pd/TiO2) illustrated the significance of strong Pd-Ti interface in this catalyst and its role in tuning the product selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation. The generation of an ample amount of oxygen vacancies in the Pd/Ti-SBA-15 catalyst with maximum metallic Pd sites in close vicinity of Ti is proposed to boost the CO2 hydrogenation activity.
coredata.dc:title: Role of metal-support interaction for atmospheric pressure CO2 hydrogenation over Pd/(Ti)-SBA-15 catalyst: Effect of titanium composition on products selectivity
